TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit ScrollBar extends System.Windows.Forms.Control
Public MustInherit Class ScrollBar Inherits Control
public ref class ScrollBar abstract : System::Windows::Forms::Control

Docs.summary: Implements the basic functionality of a scroll bar control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You typically do not inherit directly from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> class. To create your own scroll bar class, inherit from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HScrollBar> class.
> [!NOTE] > The scroll box is sometimes referred to as the scroll thumb.
To adjust the value range of the scroll bar control, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Minimum%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum%2A> properties. To adjust the distance the scroll box moves, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties. To adjust the starting point of the scroll box, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property when the control is initially displayed.
User interface guidelines suggest that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties are set relative to the size of the view that the user sees, not to the total size including the unseen part. For example, if you have a picture box with scroll bars displaying a large image, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties should be set relative to the size of the picture box, not to the size of the image.
## Examples The following example creates and initializes a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar> and adds it to a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>.
[!code-cpp[Classic VScrollBar Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic VScrollBar Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Classic VScrollBar Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic VScrollBar Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Classic VScrollBar Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic VScrollBar Example/VB/source.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public: property int LargeChange { int get(); void set(int value); };
member this.LargeChange : int with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value to be added to or subtracted from the property when the scroll box is moved a large distance.
Docs.value: A numeric value. The default value is 10.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When the user clicks in the scroll bar track on either side of the scroll box, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property changes according to the value set in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> property.
> [!NOTE] > You can handle key press events so that when the user presses the PAGE UP or PAGE DOWN key the scroll box moves.
User interface guidelines suggest that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties are set relative to the size of the view that the user sees, not to the total size including the unseen part. For example, if you have a picture box with scroll bars displaying a large image, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties should be set relative to the size of the picture box, not to the size of the image.
## Examples The following example assumes that you have created a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>, added a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PictureBox> to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>, and added a horizontal <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HScrollBar> and a vertical <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar> to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PictureBox>. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> class overview.
In this example, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> property is set relative to the size of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PictureBox>.
You must add references to the <xref:System.Drawing?displayProperty=nameWithType> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms?displayProperty=nameWithType> namespaces to run this example.
> [!NOTE] > For instructions about how to run this example in Visual Studio, see [How to: Compile and Run a Complete Windows Forms Code Example Using Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/cc447f7e-4c3b-4397-9d05-aeba3ca49416(v=vs.100)).
[!code-csharp[Classic ScrollBar Example#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar Example/CS/source.cs#2)] [!code-vb[Classic ScrollBar Example#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar Example/VB/source.vb#2)]

Docs.exception: The assigned value is less than 0.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property int Maximum { int get(); void set(int value); };
member this.Maximum : int with get, set

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the upper limit of values of the scrollable range.
Docs.value: A numeric value. The default value is 100.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You might consider adjusting the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum%2A> property dynamically to match the size of the scroll bar's parent in proportion to pixel size or to the number of rows or lines displayed.
The maximum value can only be reached programmatically. The value of a scroll bar cannot reach its maximum value through user interaction at run time. The maximum value that can be reached through user interaction is equal to 1 plus the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum%2A> property value minus the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> property value. If necessary, you can set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum%2A> property to the size of the object -1 to account for the term of 1.
## Examples The following example assumes that you have created a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>, added a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PictureBox> to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>, and added a horizontal <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HScrollBar> and a vertical <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar> to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PictureBox>. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> class overview.
In this example, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum%2A> property is set to the size of the <xref:System.Drawing.Image> plus the size of the scrollbar if it is visible plus an adjustment factor of the size of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> property.
You must add references to the <xref:System.Drawing?displayProperty=nameWithType> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms?displayProperty=nameWithType> namespaces to run this example.
> [!NOTE] > For instructions about how to run this example in Visual Studio, see [How to: Compile and Run a Complete Windows Forms Code Example Using Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/cc447f7e-4c3b-4397-9d05-aeba3ca49416(v=vs.100)).
[!code-csharp[Classic ScrollBar Example#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar Example/CS/source.cs#2)] [!code-vb[Classic ScrollBar Example#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar Example/VB/source.vb#2)]

Docs.summary: Raises the event

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> control will convert mouse wheel movements to scrolling when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> is in focus.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.OnMouseWheel%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class' method so that registered delegates receive the event.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig newslot virtual instance void OnScroll(class System.Windows.Forms.ScrollEventArgs se) cil managed
Protected Overridable Sub OnScroll (se As ScrollEventArgs)
abstract member OnScroll : System.Windows.Forms.ScrollEventArgs -> unit override this.OnScroll : System.Windows.Forms.ScrollEventArgs -> unit

Docs.param: A that contains the event data.
Docs.summary: Raises the event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.OnScroll%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
## Examples The following code example uses the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar>. Event handlers for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Scroll> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged> events are created. This code assumes that a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Label> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Button> have been created on a form and that the button has an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event. When the button is clicked, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property of the scroll bar is adjusted in code. The label will display the current value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property and the event that changed it. You will notice that when the scroll value is changed by the button's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event, only the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged> event is raised. In contrast, when the scroll bar is scrolled manually, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Scroll> event is raised immediately after the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged> event.
[!code-cpp[Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example/VB/source.vb#1)]

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class' method so that registered delegates receive the event.

## Examples The following code example uses the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar>. Event handlers for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Scroll> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged> events are created. This code assumes that a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Label> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Button> have been created on a form and that the button has an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event. When the button is clicked, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property of the scroll bar is adjusted in code. The label will display the current value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property and the event that changed it. You will notice that when the scroll value is changed by the button's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event, only the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged> event is raised. In contrast, when the scroll bar is scrolled manually, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Scroll> event is raised immediately after the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged> event.
> [!NOTE] > For instructions about how to run this example in Visual Studio, see [How to: Compile and Run a Complete Windows Forms Code Example Using Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/cc447f7e-4c3b-4397-9d05-aeba3ca49416(v=vs.100)).

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event Scroll As ScrollEventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when the scroll box has been moved by either a mouse or keyboard action.

remarks.format:
## Remarks For more information about how to handle events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
## Examples The following example scrolls an image in a picture box. It uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> of the scrollbar to redraw a new part of the image whenever the user scrolls. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> class overview.
> [!NOTE] > For instructions about how to run this example in Visual Studio, see [How to: Compile and Run a Complete Windows Forms Code Example Using Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/cc447f7e-4c3b-4397-9d05-aeba3ca49416(v=vs.100)).
[!code-csharp[Classic ScrollBar Example#3](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar Example/CS/source.cs#3)] [!code-vb[Classic ScrollBar Example#3](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar Example/VB/source.vb#3)]
The following code example uses the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar>. Event handlers for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Scroll> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged> events are created. This code assumes that a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Label> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Button> have been created on a form and that the button has an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event. When the button is clicked, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property of the scroll bar is adjusted in code. The label will display the current value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property and the event that changed it. You will notice that when the scroll value is changed by the button's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event, only the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged> event is raised. In contrast, when the scroll bar is scrolled manually, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Scroll> event is raised immediately after the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged> event.
[!code-cpp[Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example/VB/source.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public: property int SmallChange { int get(); void set(int value); };
member this.SmallChange : int with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the value to be added to or subtracted from the property when the scroll box is moved a small distance.
Docs.value: A numeric value. The default value is 1.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When the user presses one of the arrow keys or clicks one of the scroll bar buttons, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property changes according to the value set in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> property.
User interface guidelines suggest that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties are set relative to the size of the view that the user sees, not to the total size including the unseen part. For example, if you have a picture box with scroll bars displaying a large image, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties should be set relative to the size of the picture box, not to the size of the image.
## Examples The following example assumes that you have created a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>, added a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PictureBox> to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>, and added a horizontal <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HScrollBar> and a vertical <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar> to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PictureBox>. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> class overview.
In this example, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> property is set relative to the size of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PictureBox>.
You must add references to the <xref:System.Drawing?displayProperty=nameWithType> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms?displayProperty=nameWithType> namespaces to run this example.
> [!NOTE] > For instructions about how to run this example in Visual Studio, see [How to: Compile and Run a Complete Windows Forms Code Example Using Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/cc447f7e-4c3b-4397-9d05-aeba3ca49416(v=vs.100)).
[!code-csharp[Classic ScrollBar Example#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar Example/CS/source.cs#2)] [!code-vb[Classic ScrollBar Example#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar Example/VB/source.vb#2)]

Docs.exception: The assigned value is less than 0.

member this.TabStop : bool with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the user can give the focus to the control by using the TAB key.
Docs.value: if the user can give the focus to the control by using the TAB key; otherwise, false. The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks When the user presses the TAB key, the input focus is set to the next control in the tab order. Controls with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.TabStop%2A> property value of `false` are not included in the collection of controls in the tab order. You can manipulate the tab order by setting the control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.TabIndex%2A> property value.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example scrolls an image in a picture box. It uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> of the scrollbar to redraw a new part of the image whenever the user scrolls. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> class overview.
> [!NOTE] > For instructions about how to run this example in Visual Studio, see [How to: Compile and Run a Complete Windows Forms Code Example Using Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/cc447f7e-4c3b-4397-9d05-aeba3ca49416(v=vs.100)).
[!code-csharp[Classic ScrollBar Example#3](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar Example/CS/source.cs#3)] [!code-vb[Classic ScrollBar Example#3](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar Example/VB/source.vb#3)]

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event ValueChanged As EventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when the property is changed, either by a event or programmatically.

remarks.format:
## Remarks For more information about how to handle events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
## Examples The following code example uses the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar>. Event handlers for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Scroll> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged> events are created. This code assumes that a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Label> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Button> have been created on a form and that the button has an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event. When the button is clicked, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property of the scroll bar is adjusted in code. The label will display the current value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property and the event that changed it. You will notice that when the scroll value is changed by the button's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event, only the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged> event is raised. In contrast, when the scroll bar is scrolled manually, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Scroll> event is raised immediately after the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged> event.
> [!NOTE] > For instructions about how to run this example in Visual Studio, see [How to: Compile and Run a Complete Windows Forms Code Example Using Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/cc447f7e-4c3b-4397-9d05-aeba3ca49416(v=vs.100)).
[!code-cpp[Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic ScrollBar.OnScroll Example/VB/source.vb#1)]
